Our SaaS product Summarix supports us in managing CVs, project references, skills, customers, and more, enabling the seamless creation of call-for-tender documents. To make the work of our employees and sales team easier, we set out to simplify how users interact with Summarix‚Äôs structured data. Out of this ambition, Summy, our AI-powered chatbot, was born. 

We realized this project in close collaboration with SAP through the Early Adopter Care (EAC) Program for the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine, a powerful extension of the SAP HANA database. In the following sections, we will share details of the Summy project, the challenges we encountered, and the technical decisions that shaped the solution. 

The Challenge 

Summarix already provided a user-friendly UI with filtering and search capabilities built on SAP Fiori, SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) and deployed on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) . While this approach worked well for simple questions, it did have several limitations:  

  • Filters could only cover what the product owners or developers had envisioned. 
  • Complex questions across multiple entities quickly exceeded the UI‚Äôs filter options. 
  • Aggregational queries (e.g., identifying the most experienced consultant in a skill or calculating the average years of experience over all consultants) were impossible with standard filters. 

In order to overcome these challenges and accelerate the search process, we envisioned a chatbot that would be capable of: 

  • Focus on information retrieval from structured data. 
  • Provide precise, single-turn answers to questions. 
  • Leverage new SAP technologies, particularly the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine. 

This was also an opportunity for us to gain early hands-on experience with the Knowledge Graph Engine and to explore its potential.  

The Solution 

We implemented an innovative architecture built entirely on the SAP BTP. The system combines a knowledge graph and an agentic workflows to deliver precise answers to questions regarding the data stored in Summarix. 

‚ÄÉ

Key components of the solution: 

  • SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine: Stores data as a knowledge graph, facilitating SPARQL-based queries. 
  • SAP CAP backend: Manages orchestration, workflow logic, and query processing. While Python is a popular choice for many AI projects , we deliberately chose to integrate AI into our CAP (Node.js) backend using the SAP AI SDK. Utilising LangGraph.js and LangChain.js, we have modeled the agentic workflow directly in JavaScript. 
  • SAP Generative AI Hu: Provides access to LLM inference. We leverage its orchestration features and prompt templates, while retaining the flexibility to switch between models from OpenAI, Amazon, Google... 
  • Angular UI: A lightweight chat interface that runs as a shell plugin within the SAP Work Zone. 
  • Langfuse: Ensures observability and evaluation. This open-source tool enables us to trace executions, measure performance, and curate evaluation datasets. 

Key Features 

Our chatbot relies on an agentic AI workflow. While it is not a fully autonomous agent, the workflow defines a repeatable sequence of steps with conditional branches. This approach ensures consistency, reduces risks, and simplifies debugging, while still supporting dynamic, question-specific workflows and granting the agent some autonomy. 

Knowledge Graph Generation 

The project started with building the knowledge graph, which is based on the structured data from the SAP HANA Database of Summarix. This includes the following steps: 

  1. Export data from SQL into CSV. 
  1. Create graph nodes for entities (e.g., employees, projects, skills) with attributes while omitting irrelevant columns. 
  1. Model n-n relationships through connection nodes. 
  1. Export everything into Turtle (.ttl) files. 
  1. Ingest these files into the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine. 

Ensuring data quality is paramount, as errors in this area can propagate through to the chatbot and significantly impact downstream task performance. As part of the ongoing development and implementation of improvements, the knowledge graph creation process has been repeatedly revised and enhanced . 

Entity Extraction and Matching 

Users naturally phrase questions in different ways (e.g., SAP BTP vs. SAP Business Technology Platform). Since each skill has a canonical name in Summarix, robust entity matching is required. 

Our approach, involved the following steps: 

  • Extract potential entities (skills, employees, projects and customers) from the question via an LLM using few-shot learning. 
  • Normalize entity names (singular form, multiple known variations). 
  • Search with regex-based case-insensitive filters for the existing entities. 

After matching the entities, we store them in the agent state for subsequent steps. 

SPARQL Query Generation 

After identifying the entities , the next step is to generate a SPARQL query. To guide the LLM, we did a lot of context engineering and provide: 

  • Context such as identity, instructions, and current date/time. 
  • The full ontology of the knowledge graph, including attributes and relationships. 
  • Detailed descriptions of all attributes, entities and relations. 
  • Examples of valid SPARQL queries. 

For this step, we (currently) rely on GPT-4.1 for its stronger reasoning capabilities, while lighter calls use GPT-4o-mini. 

We chose to use a knowledge graph approach, although it would also be possible to directly generate SQL and execute queries against the relational SAP HANA Cloud database. In our experiments, answers based on SQL queries showed slightly lower performance compared to those derived from the knowledge graph approach. 

Evaluation and Observability 

From day one,, we prioritized evaluation at inpeek to avoid a ‚Äúblack-box‚Äù development process and to establish clear KPIs and track their development over time. The key steps of our evaluation include: 

  • Curated a baseline dataset (~30 items) with questions and ground truth answers. 
  • Built an evaluation API endpoint to automatically rerun the dataset after each iteration. 
  • Use LLM-as-a-judge scoring (0‚Äì1) to assess the correctness of an answer compared to the ground truth answer. 
  • Introduced user feedback loops: flagged chatbot answers are added to new datasets, enabling continuous improvement based on previous incorrect answers. 
  • Track additional metrics, such as latency, costs and self-correction steps. 

Key Technical Considerations 

  • Multi-tenancy: Since Summarix is a SaaS product, we implemented our own multi-tenant logic to support different environments. So far , the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph does not offer multi-tenancy capabilites.  
  • Automated KG ingestion: A tenant-aware Python job daily updates the knowledge graph as data evolves in Summarix. 
  • CAP instead of Python: By keeping everything in CAP (Node.js), we simplified integration with authentication, lifecycle management, and SAP tooling. 
  • Context engineering: Providing a complete ontology with extended descriptions is crucial for reliable SPARQL generation. 
  • Evaluation-first approach: Systematic evaluation ensured objective improvements and prevented regressions.

Conclusion 

With Summy, we explored how the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine can serve as a foundation for Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) on structured data. By combining knowledge graphs, SPARQL, LLMs and agentic workflows, we created a chatbot that can provide precise answers to complex business questions. This means consultants and sales reps can now answer tender-related questions in seconds instead of manually filtering data! 

This project demonstrated that success hinges on more than just the agent workflow, it also depends on data quality, entity mapping and evaluation pipelines. We had an excellent experience with the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine and look forward to building on this foundation for future use cases. 

There is also a Medium blog post that delves deeper into the AI Engineering aspect, as well as a SAP Success Story highlighting the use of the knowledge graph for the chatbot and our SaaS solution, Summarix

If you‚Äôd like to learn more about this project or discuss AI in the SAP ecosystem, feel free to conntact us on LinkedIn: 

Fabian H√ºni (AI Engineer)
Fabian K√ºng (SAP Expert Consultant)

entry.title: How to Test OAuth-Enabled Inbound Communication in SAP Using an API Client
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog post explains how to test OAuth-enabled inbound communication in SAP using an API client. It walks through the configuration steps and provides practical examples for validating the setup.

When working with inbound communication in SAP S/4HANA Cloud or on-premises systems, developers and integration specialists often need a lightweight tool to test APIs secured with OAuth 2.0.

While there are many API testing tools available today, this guide focuses on Bruno‚Äîa modern, open-source similar to the more established Postman. Personally I think of Postman as the old guard, and Bruno as the new pup on the block: sleek, efficient, and eager to fetch your tokens! (And yes, my love for dogs may have influenced this choice just a little.) 
                                                                         

Image was created by the author using an AI illustration tool and is original content.

 üêæ In this post, I‚Äôll walk you through how to:

  1. Configure a custom communication arrangement based on an existing communication scenario for OAuth 2.0
  2. Use an API client to test inbound communication secured with OAuth 2.0

Note: This guide assumes you already have a communication scenario that supports OAuth 2.0.

Prerequisites

  • A communication scenario in your S/4HANA system that supports OAuth 2.0
  • An API client installed on your operating system (for example, Bruno, Postman, or any equivalent tool)

So, grab your treats and let‚Äôs get our paws dirty‚ÄîBruno‚Äôs ready to sniff out those OAuth tokens and help you unleash smoother integrations!

Step 1: Enable a Custom Communication Arrangement for OAuth

1. Create a Communication System and Communication User

üêæ Think of the Communication System as Bruno‚Äôs doghouse‚Äîit needs to be cozy, secure, and ready for visitors. üêæ

Open the Communication Systems app and create a new system:

System IDZ_BRUNO
System NameZ_BRUNO


Under Technical Data:

  1. Enable Inbound Only.
  2. In OAuth 2.0 Settings: 
    • Set Client Redirect URI Type to Loopback
    • Set a path in the Path field, e.g., /bruno/redirect
          ‚Üí This becomes your Callback URL:   http://127.0.0.1/bruno/redirect (used in Step 2)

üêæ When you set the redirect path to /bruno/redirect, you‚Äôre basically telling Bruno where to wag his tail when he‚Äôs done fetching the token. üêæ

Under Users for Inbound Communication

  1.  Add a new communication user
  2.  Set Authentication Method to OAuth 2.0
  3.  Define OAuth 2.0 Client ID, e.g., Z_BRUNO_ID
  4. Enable Refresh Allowed and set Refresh Token Expiry Time, e.g., 5 Days

Save your communication system and inbound communication user for your future testing with Bruno acting as OAuth client. This user will be later used for the Authorization Code Grant with PKCE.

2. Create a Communication Arrangement

Open the Communication Arrangements app and create a new arrangement based on a communication scenario that supports OAuth 2.0 as an authentication method, e.g., SAP_COM_0053 (Purchase Order Integration).

ScenarioSAP_COM_0053 (exists only in S/4HANA Cloud)
Arrangement NameTEST_COM_0053_WITH_BRUNO
Communication System Z_BRUNO (defined earlier)

Under Inbound Communication:

 

  1. Enter the OAuth 2.0 Client ID you defined earlier: Z_BRUNO_ID.
  2. Save your communication arrangement.

Note: Only after saving the arrangement, the previously defined OAuth client gets actually created. A clickable label OAuth 2.0 Details will apear.

In OAuth 2.0 Details, you will find all the necessary data for your API client:

  1. Client ID
  2. Token Service URL
  3.  Authorization URL

These are needed to fetch a token with Bruno.

Now you are ready to test your OAuth-secured API using Bruno!


Step 2: Use Bruno to Test the OAuth Communication

Image was created by the author using an AI illustration tool and is original content.

 

 

1. Create a New Collection

üêæ  Creating a new collection in Bruno is like giving your dog a new toy‚Äîname it, set it up, and let the fun begin!  üêæ

  1. Open Bruno
  2. Create a New Collection
  3. Name it, e.g., My_test_collection

2. Set Up OAuth in the Auth Tab

  1. Go to the Auth tab and choose OAuth 2.0
  2. Set up the configurations:

     

Grant TypeAuthorization Code
Callback URLhttp://127.0.0.1/bruno/redirect
Authorization URLFrom Communication Arrangement
Access Token URLFrom Communication Arrangement
Client IDFrom Communication Arrangement
Statedummy
Use PKCE check box‚úÖenabled

üêæ  Don‚Äôt forget to enable PKCE‚Äîit‚Äôs like putting a leash on your OAuth flow. Keeps things secure and under control. üêæ

3. Send a Test Request

  1. Choose Get Access Token
  2. A browser window will open -  logon as a Business User
  3. Approve the request by clicking Allow

  4. If successful, you‚Äôll receive an Access Token. 
    The response typically appears in the Response tab in JSON format like this:

     

  5. Use this token to call your API services:


Troubleshooting Tips

  • Make sure you log in with a Business User assigned to the correct Business Roles for the API.
  • If you see the following screen after logging in:

it likely means the user lacks the required authorizations or the wrong user was used.

Summary

With this setup, you can securely test OAuth-protected endpoints in SAP using Bruno or similar tools. This approach is useful for validating integration scenarios and troubleshooting authentication issues.

Bruno provides a clean and open-source alternative to Postman for testing OAuth-secured APIs in SAP S/4HANA. With just a few configuration steps, you can simulate real-world OAuth flows and validate your communication scenarios with ease.

üêæ With Bruno by your side, testing OAuth APIs is less of a chore and more of a walk in the park. Just don‚Äôt forget the treats (a.k.a. access tokens)! üêæ

 

Image Attribution and Licensing

All illustrations in this post were created by the author using Microsoft Copilot (AI-based design tool) for educational purposes. The images are original content and free to use under the author‚Äôs permission for non-commercial, educational purposes. No external branding or promotional elements are included.

entry.title: Leveraging SAP AI Core to Build Custom AI Agents with CrewAI
entry.content:
Introduction

AI agents are becoming the go-to pattern for building modular, autonomous assistants that can think, act, and collaborate. CrewAI gives you a developer-friendly way to orchestrate these agents, while SAP AI Core provides enterprise-grade access to LLMs with proper governance, scalability, and security.

This quickstart shows you how to connect CrewAI to SAP AI Core, create a custom LLM interface, and build your first working agent ‚Äî all in under 10 minutes.

By the end, you‚Äôll have a simple CrewAI agent powered by an LLM hosted in SAP AI Core.

 

How SAP Facilitates Building Custom Agents

CrewAI handles the agent orchestration layer, while SAP AI Core hosts and manages your LLMs.  

Connecting them allows you to use SAP‚Äôs AI infrastructure directly inside your CrewAI workflows ‚Äî no external API juggling.

Here‚Äôs the high-level flow:

User Prompt ‚Üí CrewAI Agent ‚Üí Custom LLM Class ‚Üí SAP AI Core Endpoint ‚Üí Model Response

Flow summary:

  1. User sends a prompt ‚Üí CrewAI Agent receives it.
  2. Agent forwards it to a custom LLM wrapper (`SAPAILLM`).
  3. The wrapper authenticates using the token and sends the request to SAP AI Core.
  4. SAP AI Core executes the model and returns a response to the agent.
  5. CrewAI handles the output and delivers the final answer.

This setup ensures enterprise-level reliability with full control over which models your agents use.

 

Prerequisites

Before jumping in, make sure you have:

  • Access to SAP AI Core with deployed LLM models (via AI Launchpad)
  • Python 3.10+
  • VS Code or your favorite IDE
  • Installed libraries:
pip install ipykernel
pip install crewai
pip install crewai_tools
pip install generative-ai-hub-sdk[all]
pip install langchain_community
  • Your SAP AI Core Service Key downloaded as a .json file
  • Your A-game to create some amazing agents

*If you want to learn how to deploy your LLM model on launchpad, you can go through this course.

 

Step-by-Step Guide

Let us now dive into building our own custom agent which utilizes SAP's AI Core.

Step 1: Get Your SAP AI Core Credentials

In your SAP BTP Cockpit ‚Üí AI Core Instance ‚Üí Service Keys, create a new key and save it locally as credentials.json.

Example structure:

{
    "clientid": "your-client-id",
    "clientsecret": "your-client-secret",
    "url": "https://<your-region>.authentication.sap.hana.ondemand.com",
    "serviceurls": {
        "AI_API_URL": "https://***.aws.ml.hana.ondemand.com"
    }
}

This file contains everything needed to authenticate and access your deployed LLM.

Step 2: Get Your BTP LLM Access Token

We‚Äôll use this token to authenticate each request to SAP AI Core.

import json, requests

# open credentials file
with open("<path-to-file>/credentials.json", "r") as key_file:
    svcKey = json.load(key_file)
authUrl = svcKey["url"]
clientid = svcKey["clientid"]
clientsecret = svcKey["clientsecret"]
apiUrl = svcKey["serviceurls"]["AI_API_URL"]

# request token
params = {"grant_type": "client_credentials" }
resp = requests.post(f"{authUrl}/oauth/token",
                    auth=(clientid, clientsecret),
                    params=params)

BtpLlmAccessToken = resp.json()["access_token"]
print("Token retrieved successfully!")

Tokens usually expire after 1 hour. Make sure to refresh them before making multiple requests.

Step 3: Create a Custom LLM Class Template for CrewAI

CrewAI lets you define your own LLM wrappers, which means we can make one that talks directly to SAP AI Core.

In this class, we can define the procedure to use the deployed models from SAP AI Core.

You can now import this class into any CrewAI workflow to use SAP‚Äôs hosted LLMs.

from crewai import BaseLLM
from typing import Any, Dict, List, Optional, Union

class CustomLLM(BaseLLM):
    def __init__(self, model: str, api_key: str, endpoint: str, temperature: Optional[float] = None):
        super().__init__(model=model, temperature=temperature)

        self.api_key = api_key
        self.endpoint = endpoint

    def call(
        self,
        messages: Union[str, List[Dict[str, str]]],
        tools: Optional[List[dict]] = None,
        **kwargs
    ) -> Union[str, Any]:
        """Call the LLM with the given messages."""
        # Convert string to message format if needed
        if isinstance(messages, str):
            messages = [{"role": "user", "content": messages}]

        payload = {
            "messages": messages,
            "temperature": self.temperature,
            "max_tokens": 1000 # This can be modified as per your use case. You can parameterize this as well.
        }

        headers = {
            'AI-Resource-Group': "<your-resource-group-name>",
            'Content-Type': 'application/json',
            'Authorization': f'Bearer {BtpLlmAccessToken}',
        }

        # Make API call
        response = requests.post(
            self.endpoint,
            headers= headers,
            json=payload,
            timeout=30
        )
        response.raise_for_status()

        result = response.json()
        return result["choices"][0]["message"]["content"]

Step 4: Initialize your Custom LLM Class

Alright, time to bring that class to life.  

The cool thing here is that you can hook it up to any model you‚Äôve deployed in SAP AI Core, whether it‚Äôs GPT-4o, Claude, or your own fine-tuned beast.

In this example, we‚Äôll wire it up to a **GPT-4o** deployment and let CrewAI start chatting through it. You can get the deployment endpoint from your SAP AI Launchpad. You can find the payload formats for different models here.

deployment_url = "<deployment URL>" + "/chat/completions?api-version=2024-02-01"

# instantiating Custom LLM object
custom_llm = CustomLLM(
    model="gpt-4o",
    api_key=BtpLlmAccessToken,
    endpoint=deployment_url,
    temperature=0.7
)

Step 5: Build a Simple CrewAI Agent

Now that your LLM class is ready, let‚Äôs create a basic Research CrewAI agent that uses it.

from crewai import Agent, Task, Crew

# Load credentials
agent = Agent(
    role="Research Assistant",
    goal="Find and analyze information",
    backstory="You serve as a research assistant, helping to gather and analyze information about SAP tools and related topics.",
    llm=custom_llm
)

# Create and execute tasks
task = Task(
    description="Research the latest developments in SAP AI Core",
    expected_output="A comprehensive summary",
    agent=agent
)

crew = Crew(agents=[agent], tasks=[task])
result = crew.kickoff()

If all goes well, you‚Äôll see a clean response from your SAP-hosted LLM, directly through your CrewAI agent. Here is a sample output:

CrewOutput(raw="The latest developments in SAP AI Core focus on enhancing the capabilities for deploying and managing AI models in a scalable and efficient manner. SAP AI Core is part of SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and is designed to integrate with other SAP applications to streamline AI operat....ding tools that enhance productivity, and driving innovation through AI-powered solutions.", pydantic=None, json_dict=None, agent='Research Assistant', output_format=<OutputFormat.RAW: 'raw'>)], token_usage=UsageMetrics(total_tokens=0, prompt_tokens=0, cached_prompt_tokens=0, completion_tokens=0, successful_requests=0))

 

Conclusion

And that‚Äôs it ‚Äî you just built your first CrewAI agent powered by SAP AI Core.

From here, you can:

  • Add tools for the agent to interact with SAP APIs (e.g., fetching invoice data).
  • Add memory and multi-agent orchestration.
  • Deploy it on SAP BTP or your internal infrastructure for enterprise use.

This quick start gives you the foundation ‚Äî the next step is making your agent truly yours.

 

References

  • Example Payloads for Inferencing - SAP AI Core Hosted | SAP Help Portal
  • Prompt LLMs in the generative AI hub in SAP AI Core & Launchpad | SAP Tutorials

entry.title: From Docs to Dialogue: Unlock AI Self-Service Learning for Your Internal Teams
entry.content:
From Docs to Dialogue: Unlock AI Self-Service Learning for Your Internal Teams

  • Every organization wants onboarding to be faster, clearer, and less dependent on tribal knowledge.
  • NotebookLM enables the conversion of trusted product documentation and internal project artifacts into an AI-based conversational resource that employees can engage with naturally, as if they were chatting with their most knowledgeable coworker. Instead of searching across files, PDFs, and web pages, teams can ask direct questions about product behavior, setup requirements, and configuration considerations, and instantly turn answers into internal training materials.
  • This AI-driven approach
    • scales knowledge without replacing expertise
    • streamlines learning without adding process overhead
    • helps organizations build deeper product fluency internally
 

Table of Contents

  • Benefits & Use Cases
  • Gathering Trusted Knowledge
  • SAP Product Documentation
  • Other relevant documentation
  • Getting Started with NotebookLM
  • Chatbot-Driven Learning
  • Generating Internal Training Assets
  • Audio Overview: podcast interview for auditory learning
  • Infographic: a one-stop shop PDF for visual learning
  • Video Overview: a training video for visual learning
  • Flashcards and Quizzes: A hands-on tool for your team to learn
  • Best Practices
  • End-to-End overview
  • A real-world example, see NotebookLM in action
  • Prompt
  • Infographic
  • Video Overview
  • Chatbot Response
  • Considerations & Final Takeaways

Benefits & Use Cases

  • Faster employee ramp-up by turning existing SAP Documentation into a conversational AI learning environment
  • Instant answers for distributed teams across roles, experience levels, and time zones
  • Improved configuration confidence through real-time dialogue with authoritative sources
  • Consistent onboarding experiences that reduce knowledge gaps between new hires
  • Rapid training asset creation (FAQs, slide outlines, learning summaries) generated directly from source material
  • Search less, learn more‚Äîteams ask questions instead of digging across files and folders.
  • More informed internal experts because foundational questions get answered efficiently and consistently
  • Support interactions become more efficient and solution-focused when they happen, backed by deeper internal product fluency.

Gathering Trusted Knowledge

To begin using NoteBookLM as your AI Self-Service learning tool, you must first gather all of the relevant knowledge on the specific SAP product you are looking to focus on. These will become your sources within NotebookLM and will act as the knowledge base that NotebookLM uses as it guides your 

The free version of NotebookLM is limited to 50 sources, so please consider this as you capture your list of sources

SAP Product Documentation

https://help.sap.com/docs/ contains all relevant product documentation for your SAP products and is the best place to start gathering the content you need. 

  1. Go to SAP Help   
  2. Search for the specific SAP product you are looking to hone in on and then click on the Suggested Product that most aligns with your search.   
    Example: SAP Business Network for Procurement 
  3. In the bottom right corner of the top banner, click Download PDF 
  4. Select all relevant options from the pop-up page, then click Download at the bottom of the page 

Other relevant documentation

In addition to the standard SAP Product Documentation, you can gather information from various sources, including webpages, documents, PDFs, video transcripts, and raw text.

Consult with your internal security and compliance teams to review the NotebookLM terms of service before interacting with any non-public documentation 

  • SOPs (standard operating procedures) for business processes 
  • configuration specifications and customization designs
  • Project planning and scope documentation 
  • public-facing / external blogs or training content on the product or business process (YouTube videos, Blogs, industry journals, etc.) 
  • Product demos or training recording transcripts 
  • Company branding information 

Getting Started with NotebookLM

Now that you have all your sources prepared, you can begin uploading them to NotebookLM. 

  1. Open NotebookLM and complete the onboarding process to create a free account. This will be tied to your Gmail/Google account. Please consult your internal teams regarding any enterprise plans or privacy concerns.
  2. Create a new notebook, selecting the + Create New button
  3. Upload the files that you captured in the previous step by clicking Upload Files
  4. Allow your sources to load. Once complete, you should see all your sources displayed in the left panel.
  5. To share your notebook with other colleagues, you can click the Share button in the top right of the page. 

Chatbot-Driven Learning

In the middle section of the page, you can interact with the notebook via Chat, as if you were talking with a product expert. 

  • NotebookLM will then use AI to develop an answer, intentionally prioritizing your repository of sources to provide the proper context and deliver the best answer to your question.
  • Within the AI-generated response, you will notice that small numbers with circles around them are displayed throughout the answer. You can click these, and then the left panel will take you directly into the specific source document where it pulled that part of the answer from
  • For a more visual approach, you can also click the Mind Map option in the Studio panel. Once generated, you can click to view a visual representation of the sources you uploaded. As you click deeper into the mind map, the chat will auto-update and help kick-start a conversation you can use to drill down into a specific topic area. 

As with any AI LLM-based tool, results may vary and should be reviewed in detail by your teams for accuracy. 

You can continue your conversation with the AI chatbot by asking it

  • additional clarifying questions specific to your needs
  • reframing your question in more complete wording to provide more context
  • to drill down deeper into specific areas of its response 
  • to drill down deeper into specific documents/sources 
  • Additional documentation 

Generating Internal Training Assets

The right portion of the page, called Studio, will include options (depending on your plan) to generate content tailored to your team's training and enablement needs. 

For each option in the studio, click the Pencil icon to customize the result by providing a prompt that guides the studio's content generation and is tailored to your needs.

  • If you do not click the pencil, it will auto-generate based on all your sources. Depending on the size and scope of your sources, the output may be too high-level without a custom prompt provided. 

Each Studio option may also provide its own set of configuration toggles in addition to a custom prompt.

Each option also includes a Download option, allowing you to export any generated content to your internal libraries or training tools. 

Audio Overview: podcast interview for auditory learning

The audio overview option generates a one-on-one podcast interview between two people who discuss your sources and/or your custom prompt. You can use this to create targeted podcasts that dive into specific areas, then include them in onboarding materials for teams who prefer an Auditory format. 

*Pro Tip: upload your own transcript or outline of how you would like the conversation to go. This will help guide the model to create an interview that covers the areas you consider essential, rather than guessing what to highlight. 

*Pro Tip: When providing your custom prompt, include specifics as to how you would like the tone of the speakers to be. By default, the podcasts may seem a bit exaggerated at times. You can ask the prompt to use more normal and realistic tones and/or ask it to avoid certain words like "massive" or "huge", for example 

Infographic: a one-stop shop PDF for visual learning

The infographic will create a one-pager PDF with AI-generated visuals that provide a more "connect the dots" overview of the sources. It will start with a high-level overview that connects all sources (similar to a Mind Map), but if you provide a specific prompt, it can also provide a more refined overview of that topic area. 

*Pro Tip: check the visual for any discrepancies. If you see issues, recreate the infographic by changing your custom prompt to call out the mistake you want to avoid. The more specifics you provide, the better 

*Pro Tip: In your custom prompt, call out the audience that will be consuming the graphic itself. It can tailor the messaging and graphic style to better suit that audience. You can also ask it to reference a branding source if you have uploaded one that includes logos, color schemes, etc. 

Video Overview: a training video for visual learning

The video overview will provide a more traditional training format, with one speaker presenting the topic while an AI-generated video plays in the background. The video will resemble a PowerPoint presentation. You can use this to create a high-level video overview of the sources, or to provide a custom prompt that goes into one area in more detail. 

*Pro Tip: The graphics or numbers on the video itself need to be reviewed for accuracy. If you see discrepancies between what is displayed and what is mentioned in the video, you will need to refine your custom prompt and regenerate the video to close the gap. The more specific you are (e.g., an outline or script and dos and don'ts), the better the results you will get. You are unable to edit the video itself or adjust the slides/visuals after it is generated 

Flashcards and Quizzes: A hands-on tool for your team to learn 

The Flashcards option searches for primary and recurring keywords and definitions in your sources and automatically generates flashcards to help learners study/memorize key terms. 

The Quiz option will also search for primary and recurring keywords across the sources and generate an interactive question-and-answer quiz. 

*Quizzes cannot be downloaded externally 

Best Practices

  • Depending on your sources and the sheer volume of data within the notebook, the AI Models can and will hallucinate. Having detailed, specific prompts to guide each conversation or studio creation toward a specific goal will produce the best results. It is better to break your content needs into smaller groupings with detailed prompts than to blindly ask it to create high-level overviews. 
  • Be sure to consult with your internal privacy and compliance teams before uploading any non-public information into NotebookLM. As a general rule, only upload publicly available content to NotebookLM. 
  • YouTube videos can be effective at providing an additional perspective through a more expert-focused, human-guided lens on your dataset of sources. Collect long-form YouTube interviews with experts in your area and upload the URLs as additional sources to your notebook. 
  • Create your own scripts or outlines beforehand and provide those to the chat or studio in addition to your primary ask it. This will help ensure it follows the correct path you are looking for and does not hallucinate. You can also use other LLMs or AI Chatbots to help you come up with ideas and draft a high-level script or outline to follow. 
  • If you share your notebook with end users, ensure they understand that chatbot results must be reviewed and refined to provide guidance that helps kick-start an investigation into a topic. End users should be wary of copying/pasting AI-generated content externally. 

End-to-End overview

Find your product at SAP Help

Download the SAP product documentation to PDF 

Create a notebook and upload files to NotebookLM 

Observe your sources and begin interacting with the chatbot & studio

A real-world example, see NotebookLM in action

The SAP Business Network for Procurement is used globally to connect buyers and suppliers and enable interaction and transactions. This results in a variety of country-specific invoicing laws and portals that vary by country. The application itself includes standard invoicing features and built-in support for various country-specific E-Invoicing mandates. 

In this example, we will investigate how we can learn more about this topic using NotebookLM with a single prompt to generate a text answer, an infographic, and a video overview file. 

Prompt

I want to learn more about e-invoicing and country-specific invoicing rules within the SBN for the Procurement application. My team has a basic understanding of the core SBN Procurement flows, but is seeking more guidance on the e-invoicing and country-specific invoicing logic and features within the product. Can you help produce content that clarifies this for us and explains the topic in detail as it relates to the larger product? Id like to know what is supported in the app, how i would interact with these features, if there are any specific setup or customization requirements to use this, and a list of which countries are currently supported. 
The audience here is a group of corporate employees who know procurement as a whole. Keep things professional and short/sweet. Don't use any exaggerations and don't overhype with any big, bold words. Use simpler, down-to-earth professional wording. 

Infographic

Video Overview

 

Chatbot Response

Here is an overview of how SAP Business Network (SBN) handles e-invoicing and country-specific compliance.

In the context of the Procurement application, e-invoicing on SBN goes beyond emailing a PDF. The system uses structured data (cXML) to validate invoices against your business rules and the legal regulations of the supplier‚Äôs country before the invoice reaches your internal systems.

The core feature that manages this is Country/Region-Based Invoice Rules. When a supplier submits an invoice, SBN detects the originating country based on the supplier‚Äôs VAT ID prefix or address, then applies a specific set of validation rules that override default transaction rules. This ensures that suppliers in different countries ‚Äî for example Italy vs the United States ‚Äî see different required fields and localized behaviors.

The platform supports several compliance models depending on the region.

For VAT-regulated regions, particularly in the EU, Australia, and Canada, SBN enforces required tax information such as VAT IDs, supply dates, tax breakdowns, and local currency requirements.

In countries using government clearance models, where the government must approve an invoice before the buyer receives it, SBN integrates directly with national invoice platforms. Examples include KSeF (Poland), SDI (Italy), and the E-Invoice system (India).

SBN automatically applies digital signatures to invoices for many countries to ensure document integrity and authenticity.

The system also converts standard cXML invoice data into legally mandated formats required by specific governments or networks. Examples include FatturaPA (Italy) and Peppol UBL (supported in countries such as Belgium and Singapore).

Buyers interact with these features primarily through configuration rather than manual invoice transactions.

To configure rules, buyers navigate to Country-Based Invoice Rules within the Administration and Configuration settings. Here, countries can be activated and compliance requirements can be enabled or disabled, such as requiring suppliers to send tax invoice documents.

Buyers can monitor invoice submission status in their inbox. For government-connected countries, invoice history will include status updates showing government validation progress and results.

Buyers can also generate compliance visibility through built-in reporting. One example is the Supplier Legal Profile report, which shows which suppliers have completed the required tax compliance setup for their country or region.

Suppliers see a dynamic invoice creation experience based on their country. During invoice creation, suppliers are shown required local tax fields based on their location ‚Äî for example GST IDs and HSN codes in India, or Stamp Duty fields in Italy.

Suppliers in countries with strict mandates must complete a Legal Profile or Country Configuration in their account settings. This is where they enter tax registration numbers and upload any required digital certificates or identifiers for government or network compliance.

To enable these features in an SBN Buyer account, buyers must update Default Transaction Rules to allow country-based invoice rules to take precedence instead of being ignored.

Buyers must also add and activate the specific countries they trade with in Country-Based Invoice Rules.

For countries that route invoices through external networks like Peppol, buyers must register their Peppol Participant ID or equivalent identifier in their profile so suppliers can send invoices successfully.

For countries where SBN retrieves invoices directly from government portals (inbound invoice flow), buyers must configure External Document Service settings to establish a connection with the national tax authority. Examples include Poland and Romania.

SBN supports country-specific compliance logic, VAT validation, or government integration for the following countries.

Americas: Brazil, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Mexico, Peru, United States.

Asia/Pacific: Australia, China, India, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand.

Europe: Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Russia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, Ukraine, United Kingdom.

Middle East/Africa: Israel, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, UAE.

Considerations & Final Takeaways

Every organization wants onboarding to be faster, clearer, and built on trusted knowledge rather than fragmented internal know-how. NotebookLM enables teams to convert authoritative product documentation, SOPs, configuration specs, SOWs, demos, and project artifacts into a secure AI-powered conversational resource that employees can interact with naturally‚Äîlike chatting with their most knowledgeable coworker. Instead of manually searching across files and web pages, teams can ask direct questions about product capabilities, setup requirements, and configuration considerations, then instantly convert those answers into internal enablement assets such as training outlines, FAQs, flashcards, infographics, and learning summaries. When setting up your NotebookLM hub, prioritize source quality, clear document labeling, and intentional prompting during training to reduce ambiguity and improve accuracy. This approach scales product fluency across teams, streamlines learning without adding process overhead, and creates more confident, self-sufficient users‚Äîwhile ensuring that expert conversations, when needed, are informed, efficient, and outcome-driven.

entry.title: SAP Joule Data Quality KPIs: Auto-Generates and Measures KPI's to fix broken SAP Master Data Records
entry.content:
How SAP Joule can Turn Data Quality KPIs into Real Business Control

*Views expressed here are my own and doesn't represent any entity.

Every SAP-driven organization knows this truth ‚Äî even if it‚Äôs rarely said out loud:

Most business risks don‚Äôt start with strategy.

They start with bad data.

A missing tax code. A duplicate customer. An outdated BOM. An untraceable ESG metric. Individually, they look small. Collectively, they erode compliance, margins, and trust.

This is where SAP Joule changes the game ‚Äî not by adding more dashboards, but by turning data quality into an intelligent, business-aware control system.

 

The Old World: Measuring Data Too Late

In traditional SAP environments, data quality is:

  • Measured after the fact

  • Reported at aggregate level

  • Owned by IT, not the business

By the time leadership sees a data quality issue, the impact has already landed:

  • Regulatory rework

  • Production delays

  • Revenue leakage

  • Audit findings

Joule can flip this model by working at the level where risk is actually created ‚Äî the SAP data object.

 

How Joule can Generate KPIs for Real SAP Objects (Not Abstract Metrics)?

SAP landscapes are built on concrete objects:

  • Material Master (MARA, MARC)

  • Business Partner (BUT000)

  • Bills of Material (STPO)

  • Pricing Conditions (KONV)

  • Excise & Customs data (SAP GTS)

  • ESG attributes (SAP EH&S)

Joule doesn‚Äôt need to guess what to measure ‚Äî it reads how the business actually uses these objects.

Example 1: Material Master (SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì PP/MM)

The problem: A manufacturing site experiences frequent production stoppages due to incorrect or incomplete material data.

What Joule can do :

  • Identifies which material fields are mandatory for production and quality

  • Generates KPIs such as:

Material master completeness %
BOM consistency across plants
Production posting error rate

What leadership sees:

‚ÄúThree material attributes are causing 80% of production rework in two factories.‚Äù

Not a metric ‚Äî a decision trigger.

Enter SAP Joule: Data Quality That Thinks Like a Business Partner

SAP Joule brings generative AI into the SAP stack ‚Äî not as a chatbot, but as an intelligent orchestration layer across data, processes, and controls.

When applied to data quality, Joule can enable three game-changing capabilities:

Automatic KPI generation for every SAP data object
Context-aware thresholds instead of one-size-fits-all rules
Business-language explanations of data risk

Let‚Äôs break this down.

Generating Data Quality KPIs for Every SAP Data Object

SAP systems are built on standard data objects. Traditionally, teams manually decide:

Which fields matter
Which KPIs to track
Which thresholds apply

With Joule, this can become intelligent and automated.

How Joule can do in future?

Joule analyzes:

SAP object metadata (tables, fields, relationships)
Usage patterns (how often data is used downstream)
Process criticality (e.g., regulatory vs operational)
Historical data issues and corrections

From this, Joule can propose KPIs automatically, such as:

Completeness (% of mandatory fields populated)
Accuracy (rule-based and cross-object consistency)
Duplication rates
Timeliness (data freshness vs SLA)
Conformity to country-specific rules

And it does this per object, not per report. It can measure Thresholds That Actually Reflect Business Risk. A 95% completeness score doesn‚Äôt mean the same thing for:

ESG reporting
Excise tax determination
Internal planning data

This is where Joule goes beyond traditional data quality tools.

Dynamic, risk-based thresholds

Joule can:

Adjust thresholds by market, plant, or regulation
Flag materiality (which data issues truly matter)
Learn from outcomes (e.g., audit findings, rework, penalties)

Example: A missing material attribute in a non-regulated market ‚Üí warning

The same issue in a regulated market ‚Üí critical breach

Instead of ‚Äúred/amber/green and technical language for issues‚Äù , leaders see the impact of data quality issue on business.

 

Making Data Quality Understandable to Humans

Data quality often fails because it‚Äôs explained in technical language.

Joule changes that from metrics to meaning. Rather than showing:

‚Äú2.1% duplication rate in Business Partner data‚Äù

Joule can explain:

‚ÄúDuplicate customer records are increasing invoice rework and delaying cash collection in two key markets.‚Äù

This turns data governance into decision support and KPIs into actionable insight and IT controls into business confidence.

Continuous Monitoring, Not Periodic Audits

With Joule integrated into SAP:

KPIs update continuously
Threshold breaches trigger explanations, not just alerts
Data owners receive context, not noise

This supports:

S/4HANA transformations
SOX and regulatory assurance
ESG credibility

Data quality becomes a living system, not a quarterly report.

Why This Matters for Leadership

For executives, the value proposition is straightforward and compelling:

Mitigate Risk: Significantly reduces regulatory surprises and enable swift, proactive responses to emerging threats.
Optimise Operations: Eliminates operational friction, driving greater efficiency and smoother processes.
Bolster Trust: Cultivates unwavering confidence in critical business data and insights.
 

In essence, SAP Joule transforms high-quality data from a desirable aspiration into a foundational, strategic operating capability.

This marks a profound shift in data quality management. We move beyond outdated practices of merely policing data fields, escalating issues it IT language, enforcing rigid rules, or assigning blame. Instead, Joule empowers organisations to:

Understand Impact: Clearly articulate the business consequences of data issues.
Prioritise Strategically: Focus resources on what truly matters to the business.
Protect Value: Safeguard enterprise assets and drive growth at scale.

This isn't just about achieving better data quality; it's about establishing superior business control.
